respondent.name:
BABY GIRL, A MINOR CHILD UNDER THE:
AGE OF FOURTEEN YEARS, ET AL.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in Case 12-399, Adoptive Couple v. Baby Girl. Ms. Blatt?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Are you suggesting -- I don't know that the parties -- I know that the government has said that (f) doesn't apply to the father, but (d) does, so there's not a full concession on your point.  But putting that aside, if it is a father who has visitation rights, and exercising all of his support obligations, is it your position that -- that because that father's not a custodian, he has no protections whatsoever under (d) or (e)?  The State can come and take the child away from an unfit mother or father if they're the ones with custody, and that responsible parent who only has visiting rights has no protections under (d), (e), or (f)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not asking about State law --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- I'm asking about Federal law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, (d) doesn't talk about custodial rights.  I do agree that (f) talks about continued --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- custody.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, you don't think that a parent with custody -- well, you do think a parent with custody is the only definition of family, but why wouldn't a noncustodial parent with visitation rights be considered a family with that child?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm not going to State law --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could -- could I hear her answer, please?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, there is a support obligation on that unwed father.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why isn't that a parental right?  It's one of the parental rights the States enforce whether or not you want to provide support or not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So what do you do with the States that do give unwed fathers the -- that don't  support their children and who don't have an ongoing relationship the right to be considered first for adoption?  Why should we follow the definitions of South Carolina or those other States?  Why shouldn't we just give it a Federal meaning?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: As --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Your -- your argument assumes that the phrase in the statute "to prevent the breakup of the Indian family" only applies where -- where the father has custody.  I don't -- I don't know why that should be true.  If -- if that's what Congress meant, they could have put it much more narrowly.  They had a very broad phrase, "to prevent the break up of an Indian family."  And this guy is -- is the father of the child --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and they're taking the child away from him even though he wants it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that -- that is not the breakup of -- of an Indian family?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Oh, I see.  You're reading -- you're reading "Indian family" to mean something more than -- than a biological relationship, right?  You're going to hang a lot of -- a lot of other  ornaments on that phrase?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, it seems to me he's the father, the other woman's the mother, that's the -- that's the Indian family, the father, the mother, and the kid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: He's the father.  He's the father.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This isn't State law.  This is a Federal statute which uses an expansive phrase, "the breakup of the Indian family."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What's the difference with a sperm donor?  I mean, I know that you raise that in your brief.  But going back to Justice Scalia's point, if the choice is between a mother, a biological father, or a stranger, and if the father's fit, why do you think that the Federal statute requires that it be  given to a stranger rather than to the biological father when the statute defines "parent" as the biological father?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But he didn't.  I mean, he -- he said that he was prepared to surrender rights to the mother, but not to a stranger.  And when the issue of adoption came up, he said, "Yes, I want to assert my parental rights."

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Where does it -- where is there a reference in the definition of "parent" to a State law?  I see the -- which is the section that defines a parent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It says a parent means a biological parent of an Indian child and he fits that definition.  And then the next section -- the next sentence doesn't have any reference to State law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But, Ms. Blatt, if he's a  parent, why wouldn't some provision in 1912 give him some rights?  In other words, what's the point of making him a parent under that definitional section if he doesn't get any of the protections that 1912 provides for when to terminate rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But what's the point of labeling a parent if he gets no parental rights under the statute and if the termination provisions don't apply to him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But what is he supposed to --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, how are they significant?  I mean, I'm trying to understand this because if you get notice, but then you have nothing to say in the proceeding because the statute gives you no  rights and the statute doesn't provide any standards for terminating those rights --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: -- what are you supposed to do once you get notice?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I think you're not answering the question of what's the point of labeling him a parent if he gets none of the protections that the Act provides to a parent?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, wait, wait, wait. Isn't your answer 1915(a) still applies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And so 1915(a) means -- that's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So he does have a -- a considerable right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, they'll have to go through a set and decide.  They have to give it to him unless -- unless something overcomes the preference or there is good cause to the contrary.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, you're thinking about this case.  I'm thinking in general.  I think the question --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But doesn't 1915 preclude the adoptive parents because they're not in the preferred category?  If 1915(a) precludes the adoption, then the adoptive parents would have no legal basis for objecting to an award to the father.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is it your position that the preference is absolute or is it simply a factor to be considered with the other -- in other words, if every other factor suggests that the best interests of the child are served by placement with the adoptive couple, does the preference under 1915(a) trump all those other interests?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's not listed under  the -- there are guidelines for what constitutes good cause.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In -- in your view, at what point, at what date did the Indian father lose the right to ask for custody?  Because he changed his mind in -- in January, there was about a 5-day period there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The adoption proceedings had not concluded.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And at this point he said, in effect, I've changed my mind.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So the State law determines when his rights under the Federal Act end?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Unless we believe that the Federal statute determines when he has parental rights by defining "parent" to include a biological father.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If that's the case, then what you said doesn't apply.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, I wanted you to talk about (f).  Are you going to say something about that or --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- are you going to leave it to the government?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't agree with the government's position, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. Blatt, continuing on the assumption that this man is a parent under the statutory definition, what your argument seems to be suggesting is that there are really two classes of parents under the statute, right, that everybody is labeled a parent, but then there are the parents who get the protections of -- of the termination of rights provision and the parents  who don't. And I'm just wondering why if this statute creates two classes of parents it didn't say that in a more upfront kind of way?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: It seems a strange thing to read into a statute in this sort of backhanded way that there are really two kinds of parents.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Clement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What do you do with the lower court's determination that one of the factors of the best interest calculus was the Federal policy to ensure that Indian children, children of biological Indian parents, at least one, should be raised with their parents?  Because the lower court said it thought it was in the best interest of this child to stay with its birth father, in light of the Federal policy.  So I disagree with your colleague that there wasn't a best interest --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What do I do with the lower court's finding that this father, despite not being married to his prior lover, had children, was  attentive of those children, had the resources to raise the child?  What do we with -- why are you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But they looked at something else that everybody's ignoring --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Please finish.  Let's finish.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, and even in that sense, serious emotional and physical damage is a much different threshold than the best interests of the child, even on the statutory terms.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Mr. Clement, can I go back to that best interest calculus?  There's two  timeframes in my mind to look at:  In January, when he asserted his parental rights and 2 years later when the trial was heard.  If there's serious emotional harm, I think the court below said, we're not looking at what happens at the time we're deciding the custody issue because otherwise, we're going to give custody by estoppel. We're going to encourage people to hold on to kids and create the serious physical harm.  In January, when he asserted his rights, that's what we're looking at.  What was in the best interests of the child at the time the issue was raised, and that was 4 or 5 months after the birth of the child.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So we're going to freeze it at that point or are we going to freeze it today, after the child's been with his -- with her father for 2 years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't want to be that judge, by the way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about now, when you said the best interest.  Now the child has been some 15 months with the father.  So if a best interest calculus is made now, you would have to take into account uprooting that relationship, would you not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I -- and I take it you'll say that that goes back to this South Carolina court if you prevail?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If the best interest of the child is the uniformly accepted standard in State courts, and if we forget constitutional avoidance problems which I -- I think exist here, is there anything in the statute that allows us to import the best interests of the child into the statutory language, or do we have to just rely on constitutional avoidance and -- and really rewrite the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Even though -- even though the guidelines to what's good cause do not include best interest.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So what do we do about that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Finish the answer.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Rothfeld?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you think that's correct under the Act?  Where in the Act does it say that you need to consider whether or not the father is a -- would be a good parent?  I thought your reading was that it doesn't matter, all that matters is that he has in his case 3/128ths Cherokee blood.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And do you -- you want us to write the case as if this is just a standard best interest determination and -- and this federal statute is irrelevant?  I don't understand your argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you apply a "best interest of the child" standard to a termination of parental rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, can -- can -- I know a lot of kids that would be better off with different parents.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Actually, it does -- does (f) apply, in your opinion, to this case or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And (f) has something of the best interest standard tilted towards the Indian parent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is that right or not?  I mean, as I read it it's something.  It's tough, but it's there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So in your view the best interest standard does not apply, but rather (f) applies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And (f) is a tough version of a best interest standard. Have I got it right or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, how does (f) apply? It says "continued custody."  That seems to assume that custody exists.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So your argument is not that "continued" means something different from the normal language, your argument is that "custody" means something different from its normal language.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Could -- could I go back to what you just said about (f)?  You think custody covers someone who has never had custody of the child because it refers to something beyond the accepted definition?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But (f) doesn't say "child custody proceeding."  It says "continued custody of the child."

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Tell me why you are fighting Justice Breyer?  He said, I see -- and your -- Mr. Clement said the same thing -- that "good cause" under 1958 has a variant of best interests of the child or factors that are considered.  I see (f) as doing the same thing, allotting however a burden of proof that may or may not be higher than other States. I mean, in -- in -- some States may have clear and convincing evidence, some States may have preponderance.  Some States -- I don't know if any have beyond a reasonable doubt.  But it's an allocation of burden.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You should if I'm not right. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But I think Justice Breyer is quite wrong because a standard that says results in serious emotional or physical damage to the child is far from a best interest standard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It sure is.  And do you  know of any State that -- that applies best interest of the child standard to termination of parental rights as opposed to adoption?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But not me, right? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You might just have to pick --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: This is not -- (f) is not about terminating parental rights.  It's about what -- I mean, it's about custody, right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: In what proceeding, the adoption proceeding or custody determination?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If -- if you had a  tribe, is there at all a threshold before you can call, under the statute, a child an "Indian child"?  3/256ths? And what if the tribe -- what if you had a tribe with a zero percent blood requirement?  They're open for, you know, people who want to apply, who think culturally they're a Cherokee or -- or any number of fundamentally accepted conversions.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I mean, is it -- is -- would that child be considered an Indian child, so a father who had renounced any interest in her until he found out about the adoption would have all these rights?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no.  That's why I asked it.  It's a different question. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought the definition of an Indian child is just straight out of the statute.  An Indian child is someone who is either a member of a tribe or eligible, and is the biological child of a member of an Indian tribe.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So return to what is a hypothetical question and not what the statute provides.  Under your argument, a tribe that did not require any blood requirement, but simply enrollment, could be considered an Indian child.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, yes, you have somebody who has no Indian blood, he enrolls in my hypothetical tribe, has a biological child.  That child would be an Indian child and the father would be entitled to the protections you're arguing for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But that is a problem. Because, look, I mean, as it appears in this case is he had three Cherokee ancestors at the time of George Washington's father.  All right?  Now, you say, oh,  well, that's a different issue. But I don't see how to decide that case without thinking about this issue because if your view is taken and you accept that definition, a - a woman who is a rape victim who has never seen the father could, would, in fact, be at risk under this statute that the child would be taken and given to the father who has never seen it and probably just got out of prison, all right?  And you don't know that this beyond reasonable doubt standard would satisfy that. Now, that's obviously something I find disturbing, as a person and also as a judge, because we're trying to interpret the statute to avoid results that would be very far out, at least.  And -- and that's what I want you to tell me.  How do I prevent that kind of risk through an interpretation of the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Aren't there Federal definitions of approvals of tribes?  Not every group of native Americans who get together can call themselves a tribe.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And isn't one of the conditions of that a condition of blood and not -- not of voluntary membership?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm quite sure that's right.  So I think the hypothetical is -- is a null set. I don't think it ever exists.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm just wondering is 3/256ths close -- close to zero?  I mean, that's -- that's the question in terms to me, that if you have a definition, is it one drop of blood that triggers all  these extraordinary rights?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But what if a tribe makes eligibility available for anybody who, as a result of a DNA test, can establish any Indian ancestry, no matter how slight?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: No, it's different from his. He says it's -- it has to be based on blood.  This would be based on blood.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, there are two forms of the EIFD doctrine, the existing Indian family doctrine.  One applies directly to this case, what's the status of an unwed father, and they seem, under that doctrine, to apply the definition that a parent who hasn't been involved in the care during pregnancy is not a father. But the other side of the doctrine is the one that addresses, I think, the Chief's concern, which is you don't only have Indian blood, but you've been a father who's actually been a member of an Indian tribe, an active member. We don't have to reach that separate issue here, that EIFD -- that part of the EIFD doctrine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I don't disagree.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is my recollection correct that -- that he had offered to -- to marry the mother, and she rejected that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that there's some ambiguity there because one reason why he wanted to  marry was that he would get more pay and allowances.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: He was excited, but there is no doubt he paid nothing during the pregnancy and nothing at the time of the birth, right, to support the child or the mother?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So he was excited by it, he just didn't want to take any responsibility. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that -- that was after she had rejected his offer to marry her, no?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, these -- these considerations are why domestic relations pose the hardest problems for judges.  Our domestic relations judges all by themselves every day have these difficult problems.  If we could appoint King Solomon, who was the first domestic relations judge, as special master, we could do it.  But we can't do it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know why you make that concession.  I mean, your client has been deprived of parental rights.  I do not know that -- that it is traditional to decide whether a parent will be deprived of parental rights by assessing what is in the best interest of the child. That seems to me quite --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- extraordinary, not normal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But is -- is that true under South Carolina law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under South Carolina law in this adoption proceeding, the -- if it had not been for the statute, the best interest of the child standard would not have applied?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He would be out under South Carolina law because he didn't support the child during the pregnancy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Termination of parental rights requires a showing that it's an unfit parent, which is quite --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: You have an extra -- you have an extra minute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, if this case would have come out the same way under purely South Carolina law, then why are we here?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but -- did you -- at your -- when you began, do you use "paternity" in the biological sense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: As -- as you -- as you interpret the statute, "paternity is the biological sense," not -- not an --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- not an existing parental relationship.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It says that, doesn't it?  A parent is -- is the -- the biological parent.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's what it says.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, family law is traditionally a State province, but your argument is that Federal law can take a traditional family law term like "parent" and perhaps others and give it a meaning that is very different from its traditional meaning or its meaning under State law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Strike the "traditional" meaning, but its meaning under State law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Wait.  I didn't understand. Citizenship, who has acknowledged citizenship?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay.  I understand now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Mr. Kneedler, let's say you're right that this man is a parent under the terms of the Act, so not just a biological father, but also he has a legal status as parent under this Act.  And then 1912 says, well, this is how you go about terminating  parental rights, right? But then your argument suggests that one of these clauses applies to him and the other one doesn't, even though he's a parent.  But you're saying he only gets some of the protections, that there are really two classes of parents, custodial parents and non. So where does that come from?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's a very strange way to put it.  I mean, just -- just in passing in the sentence, that "the continued custody."  I mean, you would think if that's what they meant, they would say, "where the child" is -- "is within the custody of a parent, comma, no termination of parental rights may be ordered, in the absence of a determination," blah, blah, blah, blah, blah. It doesn't say that.  It says, "No termination may be ordered in absence of a determination, including testimony of a qualified expert, that the continued custody of the child by the  parent or Indian custodian is likely to result in serious emotional." When it's -- when it's framed that way, I am -- I am inclined to believe that the "continued custody" means looks to the future, the continuing custody by this person in the future.  To read into it the fact that -- that the whole provision only applies to someone who is then in custody of the child, that's very strange.  That's -- that's not the way somebody would write a provision like that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But doesn't it happen, in your interpretation, unlike the two parties who have an interpretation I can understand, that -- remember my hypothetical, which I deliberately made dramatic.  We can think of a whole range of things short of that where the father has seen the mother never, perhaps, or sperm donors for very short periods of time, and under your interpretation where there is an ongoing relationship,  even a short one, at least they can't give the child to the father where it would be very harmful to the -- to the child. But under your interpretation, the one category of people who is exempt from that are the category of fathers who've never seen the mother. Who've seen the mother a very short time.  Who may be in -- they're not even subject to looking to see if it's very harmful to the child. So I just -- am I right about your interpretation having that effect?  And if it does have that effect, what's the justification for it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  So you can say, oh, there's no such thing as a parent, a father who only sees the mother --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right.  Okay.  All right. Now, let's suppose there is such a thing. As long as there is such a thing, the anomaly that I mentioned seems to me to exist.  And am I wrong or right  about that?  And if it exists, what's the basis for your creating an interpretation of the statute that would produce it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But as a Federal overlay, Mr. Kneedler, I mean, does it make sense to sort of split apart (d) and (f) in this way?  Because (d) is the curing provision that says you have to take steps to try to cure this parent and, you know, to try to make him or her a better parent.  And then (f) says here's the standard for terminating parental rights if those curative efforts have failed.  Right? So to -- to use -- to have the curative provision but not the standard just seems to -- to make a -- a mess of the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the whole thrust of it, you -- this is directed to providing remedial services, which it -- it seems that it fits a situation where someone has custody but is having problems getting his or her act together so needs the help of a social worker, but it makes no sense to talk about remedial services for someone who has never had custody.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But he didn't want anything to do with the child if the mother had kept the child in her care.  It was only when she wanted to put it up for adoption that he had developed this interest in the child.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But what's -- is -- is -- are the would-be adoptive parents required to provide remedial services and rehabilitative programs under (d)?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So that it's a tribe -- if the tribe wants to defeat the adoption, all they have to do is do nothing with respect to the father's --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Kneedler. Ms. Blatt, you have three minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Counsel, this Act, in  terms of voluntary surrender of Indian children by parents, says that it's not final for an adoptive parent until the court does the adoption decree.  It gives the mother the right -- or father -- to rescind the voluntary adoption till the very last minute.  Has that stopped adopt -- voluntary adoptions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: MS. BLATT:  No.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: what its intent was?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That was its intent. You don't think that that's It only applies to children of -- to tribal children. And -- and the purpose was to establish much more difficult standards for the adoption of -- of a child --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, maybe you -- you disagree with that policy, but that's clearly a policy behind the law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It didn't say that. It -- its definition of --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That, Ms. Blatt, is what provoked the Act that Indian children were being removed from their families, but the Act is written in much broader terms.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
